content.instructions:
Implementation of this programme requires highly motivated and knowledgeable personnel. Also the Gram Panchayats concerned officials have to be suitably capacitated. Therefore, the Ministry of Rural Development, Govt. of India has put in place a specially designed capacity building programme and the National Institute of Rural Development and Panchayati Raj (NIRD & PR), Hyderabad has been designated as Nodal Agency to conduct the capacity building programmes for State Nodal Officers and Charge Officers of SAGY through SIRDs at the State level. Since 2017-18, NIRDPR has been conducting capacity building programmes for charge officers on regular basis. Keeping in view the importance of SAGY programme following objectives have been framed to achieve the aim of SAGY programme:

Objectives

-          To orient the participants about the importance of SAGY programme and its role in creating model villages

-          To equip the participants with the strategies of SAGY scheme for effective implementation.

-          To impart the skills and techniques of participatory rural appraisal in participants PRA for effective planning processes.

-          To demonstrate successful rural development created in SAGY Gram Panchayats.
organisation: NIRDPR National Institute of Rural Development and Panchayati Raj
content.source: NIRDPR National Institute of Rural Development and Panchayati Raj

content.description:
Saansad Adarsh Gram Yojana (SAGY), as a path breaking initiative in rural development was launched by the Hon’ble Prime Minister on 11 October 2014 with the objective of creating Adarsh Grams (Ideal Villages) across the country. The scheme Guidelines called upon the Hon’ble Members of Parliament to make one Gram Panchayat of their choice a Model Village by 2016, and another two by 2019 and thereafter every year one Gram Panchyat each year till 2024. The Hon’ble MPs have adopted in the first phase of SAGY (2014-2019) total 1510 Gram Panchayats and in the second phase of SAGY (2020-2024) which is ongoing 541 Gram Panchayats have been identified till now. These ‘Adarsh Grams’ are to serve as ‘nucleus of health, cleanliness, greenery and cordiality’ within the village community becoming schools of local development and governance, inspiring neighbouring Gram Panchayats.

The Saansad Adarsh Gram Yojana (SAGY) converges resources available from a range of existing Central Sector, Centrally Sponsored and State Schemes to achieve the programme objectives and as such, no additional funding is deemed necessary.

The Gram Panchayats under the guidance of Hon’ble MPs follow a structured process of environment-creation, social-mobilisation, resource-mapping and participatory development planning

content.instructions:
Keeping this in mind we have launched the course ‘AI for Governance: An Introduction'. This course aims at building awareness of AI and other emerging technologies among government officials enabling them to make informed data-driven decisions thereby impacting lives for the social good.

After this course, you will be able to:

  • Understand how AI-powered and other Emerging Technologies are critical for good governance
  • Identify the applications of different Emerging Technologies across sectors and government
  • Identify work problems where the use of selected AI-driven and other Emerging Technologies can provide a solution
  • Appreciate the limitation of Emerging Technologies and in which areas it may not be prudent to use these technologies
content.name: AI for Governance : An Introduction

content.description:
Welcome to the ‘AI for Governance: An Introduction' Course!

Technological advances have always been key agents of change in how we work, interact, and live. There is an unprecedented pace of technological innovation in all fields from computing and artificial intelligence to drones and virtual reality. Public Policy for any country is a complex task, and the complexity increases further if the country is as large, populous, and diverse as India. AI-based technologies provide an avenue for better decision-making and can help improve the policy-making process. In our view, these technologies supplement the experience and expertise of policymakers and aid their decision-making. As a result, we view AI not as Artificial Intelligence but as Augmented Intelligence.

content.instructions:
After going through this course, you will be able to:

  • Underline the goal of introducing different Post Office Small Savings Schemes
  • Identify different Schemes offered
  • Understand the benefits of these Schemes
content.name: Introduction to POSB Schemes

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Understands the rules and procedures in the organisation
Respects and follows the rules and other norms of working
Understands Civil Services values and acts accordingly
Executes work according to expectations
competencies_v3.name: Commitment to the Organisation
competencies_v3.description: Aligns behaviours and interests with the needs and goals of the organisation.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Aligns self with the organisation

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Pays attention to detail to obtain comprehensive information
Is knowledgeable of the policies and standards of his/her own department and adheres to them while working
Willingness to consult superiors and peers in order to validate or reconfirm the details
Respects confidential information
competencies_v3.name: Attention to Detail
competencies_v3.description: Having an underlying drive to being thorough and meticulous and to comply with procedures, rules, guidelines, and standards. Digs deeper and strives to reduce uncertainties and errors.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName:
Pays Attention 
to Detail

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Understands what is required in their role and how this contributes to the Departmental
priorities
Considers how their job impacts colleagues in their own and other Departments; takes an active interest in expanding knowledge of areas related to their role.
competencies_v3.name: Strategic Thinking
competencies_v3.description: Ability to understand the dynamic internal and external environment and its impact.  Responds to the opportunities and challenges for the betterment of the society.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Understands own work

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Is open and honest in one’s dealings with others
Honours commitments made to others
Acts in ways to avoid conflict of interest - perceived or real ”“ for example -by disclosing potential issues on time
Honest and open in all communications
Gives frank and honest opinion when sought
Follows the rules and regulations and is guided by Public Service values
Does not share information loosely with others
competencies_v3.name: Integrity
competencies_v3.description: Consistently behaves in an open, fair, and transparent manner; honours one’s commitments; and works to uphold the Public Service Values.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Acts ethically

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Extract tax and tax- related information for analysis to assist in monitoring tax risks
 Comply with tax controls and policies to aid monitoring of tax risks
Identify and follow-up on Non-compliances
competencies_v3.name: Tax Risk Management
competencies_v3.description: Review tax risk frameworks to ensure risks are minimised and managed properly
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Assist to ascertain tax risk areas

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Administer voluntary exit processes according to policies and procedures
Draft documentation required for voluntary exits
Provide information to employees on voluntary exit policies
Maintain comprehensive records of voluntary employee exits
competencies_v3.name: Voluntary Exit Management
competencies_v3.description: Establish and implement frameworks, guidelines, policies and processes to manage voluntary exits
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Administer processes for voluntary employee exits

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Aware of the benefits of stakeholder engagement, specifically towards the pursuit of short-term and long-term objectives 
Recognises relevant internal and external stakeholders
Documents internal and external stakeholder positions on organisational, project, and/or departmental goals
competencies_v3.name: Stakeholder Management
competencies_v3.description: Effectively build, engage, sustain, and manage relationships with stakeholders to ensure successful outcomes for short-term and long-term objectives.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Understands stakeholder engagement

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Understands the underlying intent of project resource management 
Describes the types of project resources required for successful execution and completion of a project (people, capital, etc.)
Recognises the characteristics of a ‘resource’ and ‘resource plan’
competencies_v3.name: Project Resource Planning
competencies_v3.description: Develop and assess project resource plans to ensure optimal resource utilisation.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Understands the intent of project resource management

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Understands the extent and scope of IoT, including its application in various domains (agriculture, healthcare, manufacturing, etc.) 
Recognises the importance of sensors and sensing techniques in adding digital intelligence to physical devices 
Visualises and communicates the intersection between human culture and digital information systems 
Aware of basic IoT terminology (IoT products, sensors, IoT smart devices, etc.)
competencies_v3.name: Internet of Things Management
competencies_v3.description: Understand, identify, interpret, and develop IoT solutions towards pre-determined objectives, and improve existing processes.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Understands IoT  scope

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Aware of various data collection sources (government websites, Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha questions, private sector reports, census data, academic journals, etc.)  
Recognises credible data sources and corresponding data collection instruments 
Distinguishes between primary and secondary sources of data 
Alerts the team if required data already exists
competencies_v3.name: Data collection and analysis
competencies_v3.description: Proactively collect, clean, analyse, and communicate data from a range of stakeholders and sources to reach a conclusion and support decision making.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Aware of data collection sources and instruments

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Understands scenario planning as a methodology for identifying and addressing risks and uncertainties
Documents current and future challenges the Indian government might face 
Aware of the rationale and objective of scenario plans (setting agenda, determining driving forces, etc.)
competencies_v3.name: Scenario Planning
competencies_v3.description: Understand and develop scenario plans to anticipate and solve for risks and uncertainties the Indian government might face, while managing social interests and government priorities.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Understands scenario planning

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Perform root cause analyses
Facilitate execution of small projects or project modules
Implement realistic project plans based on the understanding of project objectives and project scope
Utilise appropriate methods and tools to track and drive progress of projects against set plans and timelines
Identify risks to the success of projects or modules and take appropriate actions to manage them
Collaborate and communicate effectively with relevant internal and external stakeholders directly impacting the projects
Deploy resources to different parts of the projects for efficient and effective completion
Track project deliverables against project schedules
Monitor costs, timescales and resources used and take basic corrective actions in case of misalignment
competencies_v3.name: Project Management
competencies_v3.description: Plan and manage all aspects of a project, including allocation of people resources, budget and time management, stakeholder engagement and problem resolution
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Project management - Small Projects

competencies_v3.name: Wealth Planning Administration
competencies_v3.description: Manage, review and administer proposed wealth planning tools and/or structures, in accordance with the organisation's policies and procedures and wealth planning laws and regulations

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Identify relevant quality assurance standards
   Implement quality assurance practices in day-to-day tasks
   Monitor quality performance levels based on quality assurance guidelines
   Conduct random quality checks and document results to measure quality performance levels
   Identify lapses in self- quality performance levels
   Determine and/or seek guidance on how to realign quality standards for performance
competencies_v3.name: Product/Service Quality Assurance
competencies_v3.description: Develop, implement and monitor practice of clear quality expectations and standards aligned to the organisation's values and business objectives
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Adhere to quality standards and identify quality gaps

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Understands the types of project risks (internal and external) and basic ways to manage them (avoid, mitigate, transfer, and accept)
Categorises the three types of internal risks (human-factor, technological and physical)
Summarises the types of external risks based on the reliability of forecasts (economic, natural and political risks)
competencies_v3.name: Project Risk Identification
competencies_v3.description: Identify, prepare and assess for internal and external risk impacting the project using a situational analysis framework to mitigate negative effects and maximise positive effects for project success.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Aware of the types of project risks

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Implement audits and checks to determine activities are performed in accordance with SOPs
Communicate SOPs to staff 
Collate feedback from staff and determine improvement opportunities
Recommend improvements to SOPs
competencies_v3.name: Standard Operating Procedures Development
competencies_v3.description: Implement and develop Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) and enforce compliance with SOPs
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Administer operations to ensure and enforce compliance with SOPs

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Ensure mmeting current service standrads
   Develop knowledge of organisation’s product or service offerings and customer profile
   Establish customer rapport to build  customer confidence
competencies_v3.name: Service Challenges
competencies_v3.description: Develop a framework to manage and mitigate service challenges and feedback from customers
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Monitor service levels, review and report service delivery deviations

content.description: Small Savings, Big Gains
content.creator: RAKNPA Content Creation Team

content.instructions:
इस पाठ्यक्रम के पूरा होने पर, आप यह समझने में सक्षम होंगे 

  • भारतीय डाक की आवर्ती जमा योजना और इसकी मुख्य विशेषताएं
  • बचत खाते से स्वचालित हस्तांतरण की प्रक्रिया, नियम व शर्तें
  • परिपक्वता और समय से पूर्व खाता समापन की प्रक्रिया
content.name: आवर्ती जमा (आरडी)
content.purpose: आरडी में मासिक जमा करें, एकमुश्त रकम प्राप्त करें।

content.instructions:
After going through this course, you will be able to:

  • Understand the Recurring Deposit scheme of India Post and its salient features
  • Explain the subsequent deposit features and their need
  • Describe the situations when automatic transfer from a savings account is permitted
  • Identify the terms and conditions for the automatic transfer
  • Underline the guidelines for the closure of account on maturity and premature closure
content.name: Recurring Deposit (RD)
content.purpose: Deposit monthly in RD, get lump-sump

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Pays attention to detail to obtain comprehensive information
Is knowledgeable of the policies and standards of his/her own department and adheres to them while working
Willingness to consult superiors and peers in order to validate or reconfirm the details
Respects confidential information
competencies_v3.name: Attention to Detail
competencies_v3.description: Having an underlying drive to being thorough and meticulous and to comply with procedures, rules, guidelines, and standards. Digs deeper and strives to reduce uncertainties and errors.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName:
Pays Attention 
to Detail

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Understands what is required in their role and how this contributes to the Departmental
priorities
Considers how their job impacts colleagues in their own and other Departments; takes an active interest in expanding knowledge of areas related to their role.
competencies_v3.name: Strategic Thinking
competencies_v3.description: Ability to understand the dynamic internal and external environment and its impact.  Responds to the opportunities and challenges for the betterment of the society.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Understands own work

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Is open and honest in one’s dealings with others
Honours commitments made to others
Acts in ways to avoid conflict of interest - perceived or real ”“ for example -by disclosing potential issues on time
Honest and open in all communications
Gives frank and honest opinion when sought
Follows the rules and regulations and is guided by Public Service values
Does not share information loosely with others
competencies_v3.name: Integrity
competencies_v3.description: Consistently behaves in an open, fair, and transparent manner; honours one’s commitments; and works to uphold the Public Service Values.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Acts ethically

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Extract tax and tax- related information for analysis to assist in monitoring tax risks
 Comply with tax controls and policies to aid monitoring of tax risks
Identify and follow-up on Non-compliances
competencies_v3.name: Tax Risk Management
competencies_v3.description: Review tax risk frameworks to ensure risks are minimised and managed properly
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Assist to ascertain tax risk areas

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Administer voluntary exit processes according to policies and procedures
Draft documentation required for voluntary exits
Provide information to employees on voluntary exit policies
Maintain comprehensive records of voluntary employee exits
competencies_v3.name: Voluntary Exit Management
competencies_v3.description: Establish and implement frameworks, guidelines, policies and processes to manage voluntary exits
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Administer processes for voluntary employee exits

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Aware of the benefits of stakeholder engagement, specifically towards the pursuit of short-term and long-term objectives 
Recognises relevant internal and external stakeholders
Documents internal and external stakeholder positions on organisational, project, and/or departmental goals
competencies_v3.name: Stakeholder Management
competencies_v3.description: Effectively build, engage, sustain, and manage relationships with stakeholders to ensure successful outcomes for short-term and long-term objectives.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Understands stakeholder engagement

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Understands the underlying intent of project resource management 
Describes the types of project resources required for successful execution and completion of a project (people, capital, etc.)
Recognises the characteristics of a ‘resource’ and ‘resource plan’
competencies_v3.name: Project Resource Planning
competencies_v3.description: Develop and assess project resource plans to ensure optimal resource utilisation.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Understands the intent of project resource management

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Understands the extent and scope of IoT, including its application in various domains (agriculture, healthcare, manufacturing, etc.) 
Recognises the importance of sensors and sensing techniques in adding digital intelligence to physical devices 
Visualises and communicates the intersection between human culture and digital information systems 
Aware of basic IoT terminology (IoT products, sensors, IoT smart devices, etc.)
competencies_v3.name: Internet of Things Management
competencies_v3.description: Understand, identify, interpret, and develop IoT solutions towards pre-determined objectives, and improve existing processes.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Understands IoT  scope

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Aware of various data collection sources (government websites, Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha questions, private sector reports, census data, academic journals, etc.)  
Recognises credible data sources and corresponding data collection instruments 
Distinguishes between primary and secondary sources of data 
Alerts the team if required data already exists
competencies_v3.name: Data collection and analysis
competencies_v3.description: Proactively collect, clean, analyse, and communicate data from a range of stakeholders and sources to reach a conclusion and support decision making.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Aware of data collection sources and instruments

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Understands scenario planning as a methodology for identifying and addressing risks and uncertainties
Documents current and future challenges the Indian government might face 
Aware of the rationale and objective of scenario plans (setting agenda, determining driving forces, etc.)
competencies_v3.name: Scenario Planning
competencies_v3.description: Understand and develop scenario plans to anticipate and solve for risks and uncertainties the Indian government might face, while managing social interests and government priorities.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Understands scenario planning

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Perform root cause analyses
Facilitate execution of small projects or project modules
Implement realistic project plans based on the understanding of project objectives and project scope
Utilise appropriate methods and tools to track and drive progress of projects against set plans and timelines
Identify risks to the success of projects or modules and take appropriate actions to manage them
Collaborate and communicate effectively with relevant internal and external stakeholders directly impacting the projects
Deploy resources to different parts of the projects for efficient and effective completion
Track project deliverables against project schedules
Monitor costs, timescales and resources used and take basic corrective actions in case of misalignment
competencies_v3.name: Project Management
competencies_v3.description: Plan and manage all aspects of a project, including allocation of people resources, budget and time management, stakeholder engagement and problem resolution
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Project management - Small Projects

competencies_v3.name: Wealth Planning Administration
competencies_v3.description: Manage, review and administer proposed wealth planning tools and/or structures, in accordance with the organisation's policies and procedures and wealth planning laws and regulations

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Identify relevant quality assurance standards
   Implement quality assurance practices in day-to-day tasks
   Monitor quality performance levels based on quality assurance guidelines
   Conduct random quality checks and document results to measure quality performance levels
   Identify lapses in self- quality performance levels
   Determine and/or seek guidance on how to realign quality standards for performance
competencies_v3.name: Product/Service Quality Assurance
competencies_v3.description: Develop, implement and monitor practice of clear quality expectations and standards aligned to the organisation's values and business objectives
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Adhere to quality standards and identify quality gaps

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Understands the types of project risks (internal and external) and basic ways to manage them (avoid, mitigate, transfer, and accept)
Categorises the three types of internal risks (human-factor, technological and physical)
Summarises the types of external risks based on the reliability of forecasts (economic, natural and political risks)
competencies_v3.name: Project Risk Identification
competencies_v3.description: Identify, prepare and assess for internal and external risk impacting the project using a situational analysis framework to mitigate negative effects and maximise positive effects for project success.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Aware of the types of project risks

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Implement audits and checks to determine activities are performed in accordance with SOPs
Communicate SOPs to staff 
Collate feedback from staff and determine improvement opportunities
Recommend improvements to SOPs
competencies_v3.name: Standard Operating Procedures Development
competencies_v3.description: Implement and develop Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) and enforce compliance with SOPs
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Administer operations to ensure and enforce compliance with SOPs

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Recognise triggers in the service environment that may lead to potential service challenges
 Use service recovery procedures to respond to service challenges
 Escalate unresolved service challenges

content.instructions:
इस पाठ्यक्रम के पूरा होने पर, आप निम्न को समझने में सक्षम होंगेः

  • सुकन्या समृद्धि खाता (एसएसए) की मुख्य विशेषताएं
  • एसएसए खाता खोलने के लिए दिशानिर्देश
  • एसएसए खाते को बनाए रखने के लिए सामान्य दिशानिर्देश
  • एसएसए खाते में जमा करने के लिए मानदंड
  • परिपक्वता पर खाता बंद करने के लिए दिशानिर्देश
content.name: सुकन्या समृद्धि खाता

   Implement communication plans to ensure that stakeholders are constantly kept informed

content.instructions:
This course includes 2 modules, In which, it consist of 12 Lectures and one assessment test. Each lectures is  90minutes duration. The asessment test is of 30 minutes duration. The following topic are covered in this course-

  1. Site selection/investigations, general requirements and construction materials.
  2. Components, selection criteria, codal provisions and design of culverts. Components, type and selection criteria for bridges.
  3. Design of bridge superstructure & other components, submersible bridges and post training evaluations.
  4. Specific design requirements for hills and design of steel superstructure, Construction equipment, earthworks, formworks, structural concrete, steel and construction of culverts.
  5. Construction of other bridge components, specific requirements for bridges in hills, steel superstructure and post training evaluation.
  6. Inspection and maintenance of bridges and culverts.
content.name: Design, Construction and Maintenance of Minor Bridges and Culverts Including Specific Requirements in Hill Roads
content.purpose: Construction and Maintenance of Minor Bridges and Culverts Including Specific Requirements in Hill Roads

content.description:
This course provides detailed knowledge about following subjects, namely: Site selection/investigations, general requirements and construction materials, Components, selection criteria, codal provisions and design of culverts, Components, type and selection criteria for bridges, design of bridge foundations and substructure, Design of bridge superstructure & other components, submersible bridges and post training evaluations, Specific design requirements for hills and design of steel superstructure, Construction equipment, earthworks, formworks, structural concrete, steel and construction of culverts, Construction of bridge foundations and substructure, Construction of bridge superstructure, bearings, expansion joints and quality control, Construction of other bridge components, specific requirements for bridges in hills, steel superstructure and post training evaluation,Inspection and maintenance of bridges and culverts.
The expected outcome of the course is to make the concerned officers (like AE, JE, AEE and DPR consultant) familiarize with Design, Construction and Maintenance of Minor Bridges and Culverts Including Specific Requirements in Hill Roads.

content.instructions:
This Course provides detailed knowledge about Procurement of Services, Works and Contract Management in rural roads construction. This Course includes 3 modules. The first module having 3 lectures. The second and third module having 5 lectures each.  The first module consists of PMSGY Guidelines for Empanelment and Engagement of Consultants for Preparation of DPR, TOR for Preparing DPR and Consultancy Agreement. and PIU Oversight and Interaction.

The TOR for Preparing DPR includes Fixation of alignment, transect walk, land plans, Engineering surveys and investigations, Traffic assessment, Social and environment impact assessment, Design of roads, bridges, intersections, protection and drainage works and Traffic control devices and safety features, Preparation of BOQ and cost estimate, Drawings including Index map, L-Section, X-sections as per IRC ad NRRDA guidelines.

The second module includes Overview of SBD, NIT, ITB, GCC, General Conditions of Contract, General Conditions of Contract, Procurement Planning and Preparing Bid Documents, Bid Opening and Checking Responsiveness and Bid Evaluation.

The third module PMGSY Guidelines for Empanelment and Engagement of Consultants for Preparation of DPR, Payment Certificates and Financial Management, Safety, labour Laws, Social and Environment Safeguards, Management Meetings and Progress Monitoring, Dispute Resolution Mechanism.

content.instructions: This course is about Parcel Sales Manual issued by Parcel Directorate during 2021 which standardizes the processes of Parcel Sales business in Department of Posts. content.instructions: The present course contains 2 modules namely Topographical Surveys, Geometric Design and Bill of Quantities and Surveys and Investigations (Soils, Materials & Geo technical). The first module contains 12 lectures of 1:30hrs  each, while the second module contains four lectures with  1:30hrs  duration each. The first module includes Introduction to surveying, Importance of surveying, Surveying Techniques and Methods of Surveying, Surveying for DPR Preparation with Total Stations and modern techniques, Field Demo of Total Station, Alignment Fixation (Horizontal & Vertical Design), Developing cross sections of Road and Production of Drawings as part of DPR Preparation and Making BOQs and Abstract of Cost as part of DPR preparation, translating the design on to the field and checking of Design. and second module includes Soil investigation for new and existing roads, culverts and minor bridges, Laboratory and Field Testing of Soils and Aggregates.

competencies_v3.description: Understanding of the organisation’s mandate, structure, policies, processes, norms and its interface with other organisations. It also includes an understanding of the organisation’s informal structures, power dynamics, and constraints.

content.description:
Several debates in the post-independence period with regard to the administration and welfare of tribal community led to two major approaches to tribal society. On the one hand, GS Ghurye advocated the principle of assimilation whereby he held that tribal societies were in fact, Hindus who should be assimilated into the Hindu mainstream fold. On the other hand, Verrier Elwin argued that tribal societies had their unique traditions and customs which needed to be preserved. As a result, the present approach of the state has been to preserve the traditions and customs of the trial communities but at the same time prevent their isolation by introducing policies and schemes for their socio-economic development.
This course is designed to understand Racial, Cultural and Economic Classification of Tribes in India and their challenges, Development and Deprivation. The Constitution of India does not define ‘Scheduled Tribes’ as such. However, Article 366 (25) refers to Scheduled Tribes as those communities who are scheduled in accordance with Article 342 of the Constitution. According to Article 342 of the Constitution, the Scheduled Tribes are the tribes or tribal communities, or part of or groups within these tribes and tribal communities, which have been declared as such by the President through a public notification or through a subsequent amending Act of Parliament.
Adivasis is the collective name used for the many indigenous peoples of India. Adivasis often face hardships and exclusion because of physical remoteness, poverty and prevalent social prejudices. Their natural habitats, resources, customs, rituals and traditions are facing a danger of extinct. For their betterment and upliftment, Indian government started many projects and developmental programmes.
Several developmental schemes including Tribal Sub-Plan (TSP) were framed and implemented by the Central as well as State Governments and other agencies. These efforts indicate possibilities of substantial change.

content.instructions:
The Comprehensive Online Modified Module on Induction Training (COMMIT) Course has been conceptualized for the training of frontline staff functioning in various Departments in the State Governments. The modules focus majorly on development of soft skills essential for improving customer orientation and quality service delivery to the citizen for the benefit of officials functioning at cutting edge level in State Governments.
The course includes 12 behavioural and 3 functional e-Modules of total twenty-hour duration. The Course will be highly useful as part of the Induction Training Programme (ITP) for newly recruited frontline state government functionaries being implemented by the State Administrative Training Institutes (ATIs).
The course can be utilised as the online component of blended ITP, which allows officers and faculty advantage of flexibility and convenience of an online course while retaining the benefits of the face-to-face classroom experience.

content.instructions: By the end of this course, the learners will be able to understand the concept of motivation from the lens of various theories. They will be able to explore the questions like why people do what they do, what is the role of a leader in motivating and demotivating others and how the design of the jobs plays a role in motivation.
content.name: Understanding Motivation

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Access HR systems to input required information
Verify accuracy of information to be entered into HR management systems
Input data into HR management systems according to policies and procedures
Access systems to retrieve required information for report generation
Review information to ensure accuracy, reliability and sufficiency of information relevant to its intended use
Identify errors in the HR systems
Recommend improvements for increasing effectiveness of the systems
Troubleshoot minor system issues
competencies_v3.name: Human Resource Systems Management
competencies_v3.description: Establish and manage effective and efficient human resource (HR) management systems
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Operate human resource (HR) management systems

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Maintain data in HR systems according to policies and procedures
   Clarify data request requirements and timelines to confirm need, nature and intended use of data
   Perform queries on HR systems based on data request requirements
   Generate reports from HR systems
   Provide data to requesting party in a secure and confidential manner
   Document the provision of data in accordance with relevant policies and procedures
competencies_v3.name: Data Management
competencies_v3.description: Prepare, structure and manage human resource (HR) data and information to assist in the analyses of business and HR issues
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Perform data maintenance, prepare requested human resource (HR) data and generate reports

content.name: Introduction to Economics

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Understands microeconomic concepts to examine when and how the government should introduce a policy intervention
Demonstrates knowledge of the  basic theories, concepts, terminology of microeconomics (opportunity cost; incentives; trade-offs; markets and market failure)
Synthesises the application of microeconomic models to derive predictions related to different public policies (microeconomic simulation models, discrete choice models, etc.)
competencies_v3.name: Microeconomics
competencies_v3.description: Understand microeconomic theory along with its applications and develop proficiency in econometric tools with the aim of designing effective policies
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Understand basic concepts in microeconomics

content.instructions:
This module opens with a discussion of climate mitigation and adaptation before focusing on LCD modeling approaches and the use of the EFFECT model, an Energy Forecasting Framework and Emissions Consensus Tool initially developed for use in India and subsequently used in a number of other countries. Concepts such as GHG emission factors, opportunities for mitigation in power, transport, industry, households and agriculture, and the necessary enabling environment (e.g. climate finance, and institutional and capacity building) are also explored. The concepts are complemented by interactive exercises to reinforce the key lessons presented.

The power sector

Module provides step-by-step guidance on the integration of low carbon considerations into power sector planning and stakeholder engagement. It contains detailed guidance how to use the EFFECT model to analyze future interventions with a potential for greenhouse gas reduction in the power sector. It discusses data collection and associated challenges and provides a technical resource guide with information on mitigation options. This module is ideally targets decision makers, planners and modelers with a basic economics or engineering background and expertise in the power sector.

The household sector

Module aims to help decision makers, planners and modelers looks at household electricity use in rural and urban areas and how economic development can affect the future uptake and use of electrical appliances. It provides detailed guidance on how to incorporate the opportunities and challenges for GHG mitigation and low carbon scenario development. Similar to other courses it explains the use of the EFFECT model, data needs and provides a technical resource guide with information on possible mitigation opportunities such as energy efficiency, new technologies, behavioral change, and other solutions.

The transport sector

Module provides step-by-step guidance on how to integrate low carbon considerations into on-road transport planning. It explores the challenges of stakeholder engagement and consensus building given the generally disaggregated institutional structure of this sector. Detailed guidance is provided on the use of the EFFECT model , data collection and associated challenges as well as a technical resource guide with information on mitigation options for on-road transport, as well as other transport modes (air, rail, sea). This module would be most useful to decision makers, planners and modelers with a basic economics or engineering background and expertise in the transport sector, providing them.

The general data model

Module provides resources to complement each of the above modules and will be useful to the planners and modelers who will use EFFECT. It describes in a step-by-step manner how to use and navigate within the EFFECT model and explains the design conventions that EFFECT uses. It additionally explains the macro level data that is required and how this is incorporated and used within the model.
content.name: Low Carbon Development: Planning & Modelling

content.instructions:
Welcome to this course on Effective Communication!

The most frequent activity after breathing is communicating with each other. In any scenario, communicating effectively not only helps us share our thoughts but is also essential to get our work done.

Professionals need communication skills primarily to draft emails, letters, and meeting minutes.

This course will help learners understand the basics of communication and the effectiveness of communication.
content.name: Effective Communication

content.instructions: Water on Earth is a unique feature that clearly differentiates our ‘Blue Planet’ from others in the solar system. Liquid water is commonly encountered in oceans, lakes, and rivers on the Earth’s surface. The earth is 71 % water. It can be classified as: 97 % - salty and found in the oceans and 3 % - freshwater. Hence the need of wetland conservation.
content.name: River and Wetlands

content.instructions: This program is designed to help you learn the Gujarathi language so that you can read, write, and speak Gujarathi  confidently with any native person.
content.name: Gujarati Course Language

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Identify objectives of employee communication
Collate information required to prepare communication materials
Prepare employee communication materials and information kits for programmes and initiatives
Disseminate communications using pre-identified communication channels and tools
Monitor the progress of dissemination to ensure that the communications are in accordance with the
roll-out plans
Address simple queries from employees on information communicated
Gather feedback on effectiveness of various communication techniques and modes
competencies_v3.name: Employee Communication Management
competencies_v3.description: Formulate overall employee communication strategies and facilitate conversations to ensure effective and timely dissemination of pertinent information to employees
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Disseminate information to employees

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Apply feedback from others to initiate one’s learning and development
Participate in opportunities for learning and development
Use feedback from others to improve work activities and one’s performance
competencies_v3.name: Learning and Development
competencies_v3.description: Develop knowledge, skills and abilities of self or employees to support the capability development needs of the organisation
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Participate in opportunities for personal learning and development

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Ability to apply methods of analysing outcomes of learner profile and learning needs
Deploy the most appropriate types of learning modes
Use the instructional methods appropriately
Use types of learning activities, solutions and technology tools
Able to identify the characteristics of active learning and improvise given methods
Can deploy techniques for managing group dynamics
Is adept at online, face-to-face, verbal and non-verbal facilitation techniques and communication techniques
competencies_v3.name: Learning Experience Delivery
competencies_v3.description: Drive learning delivery activities to facilitate learning experiences, knowledge transfer and skills application
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Implement Learning Experience methodologies outlined

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Disseminate information about learning and development programmes
  Respond to routine enquiries from employees related to learning and development programmes
  Coordinate the arrangement of venues and resources required
  Communicate with training providers on their requirements
  Track registrations and attendance for the learning and development programmes
  Apply for grants for learning programmes
  Gather learning effectiveness feedback
  Generate learning effectiveness reports
  Maintain systems for the generation of learning effectiveness reports and storage of learning and development data
  Report learning and development expenses for specified time periods
competencies_v3.name: Learning and Development Programme Management
competencies_v3.description: Establish and implement learning and development programmes and channels to facilitate employees' growth and capability building
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Support the execution of L&D programmes

content.instructions:
Did you know you might already be helping SMEs in the forest sector? Look around you. The wooden door to your office or house, the table you are using, the pencil in your pencil holder, and even the shea butter in your cosmetics or soaps, all involve wood or forest products. The value chain for one or more of these items probably involved SMEs in the forest sector. This should make you feel good as SMEs in the forest sector can help address climate change, create jobs and contribute to growth. There, however, is more we can do to help these SMEs. This webinar aims to present the world of SMEs in the forest sector. These enterprises are key for increasing sustainable livelihoods of forest-dependent people, for managing and protecting the natural resources and biodiversity of the forests and for combating climate change. SMFEs constitute 80–90 percent of enterprises in the forest sector. As development practitioners explore ways to ensure inclusive growth, SMEs present an effective vehicle for such development. This webinar is the first in a series of webinars that will discuss opportunities for SMEs given emerging markets, new business models, competitiveness and know-how insights, financial instruments and opportunities for foreign investors. The series will also present successful examples to illustrate the opportunities for multisectoral approaches that ensure growth and sustainability goals are met. In this webinar, the Global Leads from the three World Bank Global Practices on Environment and Natural Resource Management, Trade and Competitiveness and Finance and Markets will give an overview of the key issues and opportunities for SMEs related to their sector of expertise.

 

About the presenters:

Ellen Olafsen:
Ellen Olafsen is a Senior Private Sector Specialist in the Innovation & Entrepreneurship Unit of the World Bank Group's Trade & Competitiveness Global Practice. She has been working in the field of entrepreneurship for over a decade and has developed significant regional experience, including in Sub-Saharan Africa, Middle East, North Africa, Central and South Asia, as well as Central America. She oversees two programs on digital and agribusiness entrepreneurship, both of which started under her leadership. Currently, Ellen is initiating a World Bank flagship study on growth entrepreneurship intended to inform the design of Bank's projects in this area. Before joining the Trade & Competitiveness Global Practice, Ellen worked for the Grassroots Business Department in IFC (now Grassroots Business Fund), the Development Gateway at the World Bank, and Citizens Energy International in Angola. Ellen holds an MBA in International Finance and an MA in International Affairs focused on Sub-Saharan Africa.

 

Paola Agostini
Paola Agostini is the Global Lead for Forests, Landscapes and Ecosystem at the World Bank Environment and Natural Resources GP. In the last 20 years and in different positions at the World Bank she has been working on projects at the interface of Environment and Agriculture in both Africa and Latin America with a particular focus on Sustainable Land Management, Protected Areas, Forests, Payment of Ecosystem Services and Territorial Development. She was also based in FAO Rome for more than 8 years, where she was the World Bank focal point for the Rome UN based organizations. In addition she has been leading TerrAfrica Partnership on Sustainable Land Management. She holds a PhD in Economics from University of California-San Diego and a Master of Art in Economics and Social Sciences from Universita Bocconi, Milano.

 

Roy Parizat
Roy Parizat works as a Senior Private Sector Specialist in T&Cs Global T&C Agribusiness Team. His work is focused on expanding the ability of high-growth agribusiness SMEs to overcome constraints so as to create value, generate rural jobs and raise incomes. Prior to joining T&C, Roy worked in the Agriculture Global Practice of the WBG coordinating the activities of the AgriFin network, focused on expanding access to finance for agricultural smallholders and enterprises. Roy began his career with Barclays Bank, working both in the UK and in Africa, before moving into the sustainable trade arena where he worked with agribusinesses and cooperatives across Africa and Latin America. Roy has an MSc from the London School of Economics.

 

Diji Chandrasekharan Behr
Diji Chandrasekharan Behr is a Senior Natural Resource Economist in the Environment and Natural Resources Global Practice at the World Bank, and is based in Hanoi. She is, along with colleagues from the Global practice of Trade and Competitiveness and Finance and Markets, co-leading the programmatic analytical work on Enhancing Contribution of Small and Medium Enterprises in the Forest Sector to Poverty Reduction, Jobs and Growth. At the World Bank, Diji has been involved with operations and analytical work focused on using natural assets for sustainable, resilient, and inclusive growth. Her focus on SMEs started with her work on rethinking forest partnerships and benefit sharing. Diji has an MSc in Applied and Agricultural Economics from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, and a PhD in Natural Resource Management and Policy from Cornell University.

 

Jana Malinska
Jana Malinska is a Senior Private Sector Specialist in the Innovation & Entrepreneurship Unit of the World Bank Group's Trade & Competitiveness Global Practice. She has over 15 years of experience in managing SME business support, innovation and investment projects. She has helped governments and business leaders promote economic reforms in over 40 countries in Middle East, North and South Africa, Asia, and South East Europe. She currently leads SME linkage, agribusiness entrepreneurship and forestry SME initiatives and earlier, she initiated and led the Climate Business Innovation Network, Subnational Doing Business studies and business reform advisory. Before joining the World Bank Group, Jana worked with the OECD advisory unit to the Secretary General and investment division, PSA Peugeot Citroen strategic services and CzechInvest, national business development and investment promotion agency. Jana holds an MSc from London School of Economics, MBA from Universite Jean Moulin and Engineer Degree from University of Economics in Prague.

content.instructions:
As the world seeks to enhance global greenhouse gas (GHG) mitigation efforts, countries are exploring innovative and cost-effective ways to scale-up emissions reductions and foster private sector investment. A range of policy instruments such as voluntary, regulatory and market-based approaches can help achieve these goals. This course will assist you to plan, design and implement these policy instruments to help spur your country into a low emissions development path.

The course starts by discussing the rationale for Low Emissions Development (LED) policy and the expected benefits of such policies. The discussion considers both contributions to global emissions reductions and local development opportunities such as:

  • Increased energy security by reducing the dependence on fossil fuels and exposure to volatile prices.
  • Increased industrial productivity as a consequence of energy efficiency measures.
  • New economic opportunities and employment through deployment and diffusion of low carbon technologies.
  • Reduced costs of environmental degradation.

The course continues with a broad overview of LED policy instruments and is enriched with examples of how these instruments have been implemented worldwide. Individual lessons provide more details on the design and implementation of specific policy approaches, including information and labeling programs, voluntary industrial agreements, performance and technology standards for the industries and vehicles, emissions trading systems, and carbon taxes.

The course finalizes by providing policy diagnosis tools and strategic guidance for policy implementation. The diagnosis tools can help countries to identify and select policy instruments suitable to their specific needs.

To facilitate learning, in-depth policy case studies provide participants with the opportunity to identify how policy instruments may be designed and implemented in practice.
content.name: Policy Instruments for Low Emissions Development: From Design to Implementation

content.instructions:
The e-Learning Course on Energy Efficiency in Public Buildings equips different stakeholders with technical and program management skills, tools and knowledge on the “how” of identifying, developing and implementing energy efficiency (EE) programs in public buildings. This course consists of eight modules with multiple lessons in each, presenting key EE concepts and providing opportunities to apply and discuss them. This Course is designed to be highly participatory and to stimulate thinking as you learn about the different issues, challenges and strategies for improving Energy Efficiency (EE) in public sector and define how to apply the concepts and exercises presented herein to your own needs. To maximize the benefits of the course, it is necessary to complete all the required Modules and the exercises in each.

The e-Learning Course was developed under LLI-CC’s Program “Scaling up Climate Friendly Energy Efficiency Policies across South East Europe,” which is a technical assistance program funded by the Austrian government and implemented by Leadership, Learning and Innovation Climate Change (LLI-CC) practice. The main objective of the program is to scale up climate friendly energy efficiency policies across Southeast Europe, helping the targeted countries achieve smart, sustainable, and inclusive growth, and equip them with the necessary capacity needed for the European Union (EU) accession process and-ultimately-for contributing to EU efforts to meet the “20-20-20” targets.
content.name: Energy Efficiency in Public Buildings

content.instructions:
In this course, you will learn the basics on how economically viable climate-resilient development plans are developed.

The course provides an overview on changes in climate patterns already underway and what changes are projected for the future. It is explained why business-as-usual development is not adequate in response to the impacts that result from these changes. Instead the course outlines how impacts are to be managed, including in relation to addressing the challenges of uncertainty surrounding climate impacts in the future. Methods to select and prioritise adaptation options that include their costs are explained.

This is achieved through the explanation of a practical framework that helps break down the process involved. In this way, the course helps the user to understand firstly how to frame the problem, to make it a challenge that can be realistically addressed. Then the user learns how to identify relevant climate change risks and impacts so as to determine adaptation options. Ultimately the user is shown how to prioritise the most favourable adaptation option.
content.name: Economics of Climate-Resilient Development

competencies_v3.name: Climate-Resilient Development
competencies_v3.description: Identify, evaluate, select, implement, and adjust actions to reduce climate vulnerabilities and improve development outcomes.

content.description: The course is based upon the principles of multiple stakeholder inputs and includes ideas on how different expertise and views are found and incorporated. To conclude the course, a policy scenario presents the course user with the opportunity to see how an economically viable climate resilient development plan may be designed in practice.

The World Bank’s Climate Change Action Plan, aligned with the historic Paris Climate Agreement emphasizes the need to mitigate climate change by accelerating climate action through carbon markets and pricing.

Welcome to this online learning stop that brings to you a library of leading edge knowledge on carbon pricing and its associated topics through deep dive structured courses, knowledge nuggets and web seminars.

content.instructions:
Throughout the course, economic terms and notions are explained in plain English and are amply illustrated by graphs and animations for increased understanding (... and entertainment!). Each module begins with a 'Story' simulation in which you, the course participant, act as the member of a fictional committee, a 'think tank' who must assist Doreen, your Minister of Health, in improving the health system of her country using economics-based decisions. And each module concludes with a set of interactive reviewing exercises to solidify your knowledge of newly acquired material.

The ten thematic modules of the course are grouped in three clusters, each following its own color scheme for easy recognition:

Cluster 1:

Contains two modules: 1. Efficiency and 2. Equity - two examples of why Health Economics is important as a topic of study. Efficiency is a particularly good example of how Health Economics concepts can be used to foster communication between Ministries of Finance and Ministries of Health. Another example is equity, which studies how health benefits are distributed among the population of a country. Knowledge about equity in health can equip a Minister of Health to restructure the Health System so that benefits are more fairly distributed.

 

Cluster 2:

Gives a step-by-step introduction to the market mechanism. The five modules, numbered 3 through 7, help us understand what health care markets are. We will cover supply and demand and how they interact, as well as what problems exist with markets in health in particular. The Story covers all five modules of this cluster and, as you can read in Module 3, we find Minister Doreen in a prickly dilemma: which donor agency is speaking the truth as to whether to use markets or not in health care provision.

 

Cluster 3

Finally deals with who pays for what in the health sector. This is an important area and it touches on issues that we explored both in Clusters 1 and 2 such as equity, efficiency and market failures. We will look at resource mobilization for the health sector; at risk-pooling which explores how we can mitigate risks across different population groups and across time; and finally at how we allocate these resources in order to pay providers of care.
content.name: Basics of health economics

content.instructions: This course on Retirement Planning aims to develop competencies in government employees to enable them to formulate and implement retirement plans best suited to their needs and circumstances. The first module - Basics of Retirement Planning -  introduces the participants to the subject and explains the importance of retirement planning for government employees. Then basic concepts of financial planning for retirement are discussed. The second module - Retirement Planning Process - discusses the steps in the retirement planning process as well as advantages and disadvantages of investment in various asset classes. The third module - Post-retirement Investment Strategies - begins with discussion on a case study.  Then investment strategies for post-retirement period are discussed. Finally, the key learnings from the course are highlighted. Though this course is designed to meet the specific needs of government employees, it can also be used by others who are interested in planning for retirement.
content.name: Retirement Planning for Government Employees

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Apply feedback from others to initiate one’s learning and development
Participate in opportunities for learning and development
Use feedback from others to improve work activities and one’s performance
competencies_v3.name: Learning and Development
competencies_v3.description: Develop knowledge, skills and abilities of self or employees to support the capability development needs of the organisation
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Participate in opportunities for personal learning and development

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Examine internal and external influences that impact learning and development
Identify organisation’s existing capability levels and gaps
Develop learning and development strategies to support organisation’s need on capability development
Consult key stakeholders on the development of capability development strategies
Evaluate the effectiveness of learning and development strategies
Refine learning and development strategies based on evaluation results
competencies_v3.name: Learning and Development Strategy
competencies_v3.description: Drive a learning and development culture with strategies to build the organisation's workforce capability
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Develop L&D strategies to build organisation capability

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Disseminate information about learning and development programmes
  Respond to routine enquiries from employees related to learning and development programmes
  Coordinate the arrangement of venues and resources required
  Communicate with training providers on their requirements
  Track registrations and attendance for the learning and development programmes
  Apply for grants for learning programmes
  Gather learning effectiveness feedback
  Generate learning effectiveness reports
  Maintain systems for the generation of learning effectiveness reports and storage of learning and development data
  Report learning and development expenses for specified time periods
competencies_v3.name: Learning and Development Programme Management
competencies_v3.description: Establish and implement learning and development programmes and channels to facilitate employees' growth and capability building
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Support the execution of L&D programmes

content.instructions:
The course provides a clear understanding on how to undertake policy research as well as highlighting the realities of undertaking research. The course guides to the research process and with the necessary knowledge and skills to undertake a piece of policy research .

 
The course has been divided into four modules, I, II , III and IV. Each module deals with a concept, which has been explained by an Audio/Video, Essential Readings.  The participants are encouraged to explore the additional reading being provided in each module.  There is an assessment in each module to test the understanding of the concepts.
 

The course introduces to a range of approaches, strategies and methods with enables you to make an informed choice about the most suitable to your own research project and be able to justify this choice.  The prime objective of the course is to facilitate the scientific decision making in Public policy.
organisation: NACIN National Academy Of Customs Indirect Taxes And Narcotics
content.source: NACIN National Academy Of Customs Indirect Taxes And Narcotics
content.name: Basics of Public Policy Research

competencies_v3.name: Seeking Information
competencies_v3.description: An underlying curiosity to know more about things, people, or issues. This includes ‘digging’ for exact information and keeping up-to-date with relevant knowledge.

competencies_v3.name: Attention to Detail
competencies_v3.description: Having an underlying drive to being thorough and meticulous and to comply with procedures, rules, guidelines, and standards. Digs deeper and strives to reduce uncertainties and errors.

competencies_v3.name: Taking Accountability
competencies_v3.description: Takes ownership for outcomes (successes or failures) while addressing performance issues fairly and promptly.

competencies_v3.name: Result Orientation
competencies_v3.description: High drive for achieving targets and competing against a standard of excellence.

competencies_v3.name: Conceptual Thinking
competencies_v3.description: Understanding a situation or environment by putting the pieces together and identifying patterns that may not be obviously related. Connecting the dots while resisting stereotyping.

competencies_v3.name: Leading Others
competencies_v3.description: Ability to engage, energise and enable the team to excel.

competencies_v3.name: Self-Confidence
competencies_v3.description: Belief in own capability to accomplish a task and being able to express confidence in dealing with challenging circumstances, without being arrogant or boastful.

competencies_v3.name: Decision Making
competencies_v3.description: Makes timely decisions that take into account relevant facts, tasks, goals, constraints, risks and conflicting points of view.

competencies_v3.name: Consultation and Consensus Building
competencies_v3.description: Ability to identify the stakeholders and influencers, seek their views and concerns through formal and informal channels. Build consensus through dialogue, persuasion, reconciliation of diverse views/interests and trusting relationships.

competencies_v3.name: Data Storytelling and Visualisation
competencies_v3.description: Combine data insights, dynamic visual displays with illustrative and interactive graphics and narrative representative formats to present patterns, trends, meaninging, messages and analytical insights from data or new concepts in a strategic manner

content.description:
Public Administration is the study of the management, operation, and functioning
of government bodies and organizations in the public sector. As such, it is not
unique: other disciplines study this subject as well. Public Administration (PA)
distinguishes itself, though, by analysing the public sector from several angles in
an integrated manner. In other words, it is interdisciplinary in character,
employing knowledge from various disciplines in an integrated manner – or at
least it is a multidisciplinary form of research, which applies the insights from
different disciplines to one and the same subject.

Apart from its interdisciplinary approach, Public Administration research has
three other distinctive features. These unique features all influence the way in
which research is conducted.
Public organizations rely heavily on accurate data to make timely decisions regarding budgets, public policy, program implementation and general organization priorities. 
In order to accomplish these objectives, public administrators must quickly collect, analyze and interpret data.

content.name: Understanding Financial Position of an organization

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Understands microeconomic concepts to examine when and how the government should introduce a policy intervention
Demonstrates knowledge of the  basic theories, concepts, terminology of microeconomics (opportunity cost; incentives; trade-offs; markets and market failure)
Synthesises the application of microeconomic models to derive predictions related to different public policies (microeconomic simulation models, discrete choice models, etc.)
competencies_v3.name: Microeconomics
competencies_v3.description: Understand microeconomic theory along with its applications and develop proficiency in econometric tools with the aim of designing effective policies
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Understand basic concepts in microeconomics

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Maintain data in HR systems according to policies and procedures
   Clarify data request requirements and timelines to confirm need, nature and intended use of data
   Perform queries on HR systems based on data request requirements
   Generate reports from HR systems
   Provide data to requesting party in a secure and confidential manner
   Document the provision of data in accordance with relevant policies and procedures
competencies_v3.name: Data Management
competencies_v3.description: Prepare, structure and manage human resource (HR) data and information to assist in the analyses of business and HR issues
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Perform data maintenance, prepare requested human resource (HR) data and generate reports

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Recognises the different types of change(s) that can occur within a department, project, or organisation (adaptive, transformative, etc.) 
Gathers resources to support the initial stages of change formulation 
Understands the compelling need for a change initiative 
Suggests incremental changes, as determined through day-to-day experiences
competencies_v3.name: Change Management
competencies_v3.description: Understands, contributes and drives the implementation of change management processes required for effectively supporting, planning,  implementing, evaluating and sustaining change.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Programme Management

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Identify ICT energy trends that could impact the organisation
 Monitor the organisation's utilisation of energy and other resources against availability of supply sources and external standards
 Identify gaps, issues, or critical areas for energy conservation
competencies_v3.name: Sustainability Management
competencies_v3.description:
Plan, develop and roll out of an organisation-wide sustainability strategy. This includes the assessment of the organisation's utilisation and/or consumption of energy and other resources, vis-a-vis the availability and stability of supply sources and external best practices and standards in sustainability. This also includes the on-going monitoring and tracking of energy and/or resource-consumption over time, to identify impact on the organisation's internal and external environment as well as potential improvements in energy- or resource-
efficiency.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Optimise utilisation

competencies_v3.name: Sustainability Management
competencies_v3.description:
Plan, develop and roll out of an organisation-wide sustainability strategy. This includes the assessment of the organisation's utilisation and/or consumption of energy and other resources, vis-a-vis the availability and stability of supply sources and external best practices and standards in sustainability. This also includes the on-going monitoring and tracking of energy and/or resource-consumption over time, to identify impact on the organisation's internal and external environment as well as potential improvements in energy- or resource-
efficiency.

content.instructions: This course is aimed at understanding the emerging challenges in rapidly changing world and to enable officials to use that understanding while planning to solve a problem.
content.name: Public Policy and the VUCA World

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Demonstrates that policy analysis can be used across the stages of a policy life-cycle
Categorises tools and techniques of policy analysis (cost-benefit analysis, critical path method, etc.) into their elements (policy goals, means for achieving goals, etc.)
Identifies what policy analysis approach to use, based on the policy problem
Documents relevant evidence-based models for policy analysis (process model, group model, rational model, etc.)
Conducts preliminary cleaning of data based on policy monitoring and evaluation processes
competencies_v3.name: Policy Analysis
competencies_v3.description: Understand, gather, and evaluate qualitative and quantitative evidence to conduct relevant policy analyses, to support public policy processes.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Identifies what policy analysis to use based on policy problem

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Demonstrates the importance of effective policy implementation,  with a focus on good governance principles 
Provides research towards policy implementation plans (identifying resources, documenting best practices, determining relevant stakeholders, etc.)
Categorises policy implementation instruments as substantive and procedural policy instruments, keeping in mind the level of state capacity required 
Aligns the 3 elements of policy implementation (project management, participation, and public relations) to the government mantra of ‘Reform, Perform, and Transform’
competencies_v3.name: Policy Implementation
competencies_v3.description: Support and drive policy implementation to create appropriate policy systems that align government priorities.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Understands policy implementation

competencies_v3.selectedLevelDescription:
Applies historical trends to contemporary policy development cycles 
Diagnoses policy problems by identifying patterns and relationships across sources of information
Documents information and interacts with relevant stakeholders to identify policy development priorities within formal and informal institutions 
Maintains an updated database of major policies in India, including implementation statistics, upcoming evaluation programmes, academic literature, potential changes, etc.
competencies_v3.name: Policy Development
competencies_v3.description: Understand, examine, and forecast policy development cycles, specifically in India, to ensure alignment with government priorities.
competencies_v3.selectedLevelName: Supports identification of policy development priorities

content.description: Each stage of public policy has significance and its success or failure is dependent on the comprehensive understanding of the challenges at each stage by the policy makers and the implementers. The challenge is to respond to highly dynamic world and increasing demands and rising aspirations of the citizens, which in policy lexicon has emerged as VUCA (Volatile, Uncertain, Complex and Ambiguous) world.
content.creator: Dr Sachin Chowdhry

content.instructions:
Cyber security is the collection of tools, policies, security concepts, security safeguards, guidelines, risk management approaches, actions, best practices, assurance and technologies that can be used to protect the cyber environment, an organization and user’s assets. Organization and user’s assets include connected computing devices, personnel, infrastructure, applications, services, telecommunications systems, and the totality of transmitted and/or stored information in the cyber environment.

Today, cyberspace is rapidly evolving, and it can even be used as a new battleground for conflicts between States. Cyber space offers innovative challenges to States for many reasons:

 (i) it falls under few international regulations,

(ii) it tends to ignore state borders, and

 (iii) it does not always differentiate between the public and the private spheres.
content.name: Cyber Security  and Strategy

content.instructions:
This course is designed to augment behavioural competency among the participants. It aims towards civil services capacity building by standardising and harmonising the shared understanding of co-operative federalism. It expounds on federal architectures that exist in the world and India in particular. It would enable them in narrowing down the inconsistencies in training priorities, competencies, and pedagogy.


Participants would gain conceptual clarity and comprehensive knowledge about federations. The module answers 4 W’s- What (concept), Why (importance), When (evolution), Where (federations in the world), and How (functions, roles, activities, and competencies of different federal units). Learners would also get exposure to the intricate relationship between Indian diversity and federal structure. Thus it would help them in being respectful and sensitive to citizens while performing citizen-centric service delivery. Hence, after completing the module, participants are expected to be proactive and polite in delivering citizen-centric services, silo-less performance, and leveraging the democratised civil services.
content.name: Public Finance under Co-operative Federalism

content.instructions:
This module explains basic constructs of e-governance – the strategy of employing digital technologies in accelerating the processes of governance and the related concepts associated with it. It also describes in an easy-to-understand manner the flagship Digital India program of the Government of India. After the completion of the module”, the learners would be able to : 

1.Explain the terms “Information Communication Technologies- ICTs”, “Emerging technologies-ETs”  and “Digital Technologies” with related examples.

2.Appreciate the advantages and disadvantages of digital technologies

3.Understand the term ‘Governance’

4.Differentiate between “Governance” and “Government

5.Understand the aim of governance with special reference to eight characteristics of good governance

6.List some of the ills of Governance

7.List primary stakeholders of Governance and types of possible interactions using digital technologies.

8.State the basic definition of “e-governance” and its examples both in the Indian context and elsewhere

9.Differentiate between the terms ‘e-government” and “e-governance”

10.Delineate the vision and pillars of the Digital India Programme of India.

11. Understand the role of digital technologies in achieving 17 SDGs
content.name: Basics of e-Governance & Digital India
